question: Which of the following is/are sign of fracture?
exp: Sure signs of fracture:- 1 Abnormal mobility(best) 2 Failure to transmit movements proximally 3 Crepitus 4 Tenderness(Commonest sign)

question: The posterolateral lesion in the head of humerus in cases of recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation is:
exp: Complication of shoulder dislocation: Banka's anterior glenoid labrum: anterior tear in anterior dislocation Hill Sach's at head of Humerus: posterolateral defect in anterior dislocation Reverse Hill Sach's - anteromedial defect in posterior dislocation Light bulb signis seen on AP radiographs in theposterior dislocation shoulder, where the humerus head appears as a light bulb Note-M/c complication of ant. dislocation of shoulder is reccurent shoulder disclocation

question: Which of the following fracture is known for Malunion?
exp: SCFH is known for malunion- gun stock defrmity. other fractures complication is non union.

question: Which of the following is test of posterior glenohumeral instability:
exp: Posterior Instability (Adduction and internal rotation force) Jerk (provocative) test Posterior apprehension test Posterior clunk test Push-Pull test Anterior Instability Tests Fulcrum test Crank test Surprise test (most accurate) Jobe relocation test

question: Which of the following displacement does not occur in Colle's fracture?
exp: Proximal shift or impaction occurs in fracture of lower end of radius. Dorsal or posterior tilt is most commonly caused by Colles fracture. It is extra-aicular fracture. Displacements in Colle's fracture Dorsal-tilt and shift Lateral tilt and shift Impaction Supination

question: Which of the following is not a complication of a malunited Colles fracture:
exp: Rupture of extensor pollicis longus is a complication of colles fracture NOT Flexor pollicis longus. COMPLICATIONS:- Extensor pollicis longus rupture Loss of reduction and secondary deformity Median nerve compression Distal radioulnar joint injury Extension of Colles fracture into the RU joint has a worse prognosis.

question: All the following are True about the pulled elbow except?
exp: Pulled elbow Dislocation of the radial head from the annular ligament is a fairly common injury in children under the age of 6 years. There may be a history of the child being jerked by the arm and subsequently complaining of pain and inability to use the arm. The arm is held more or less immobile with the elbow fully extended and the forearm pronated. The diagnosis is essentially clinical, although radiographs are usually obtained to exclude a fracture. It is treated by fully supinating the forearm.
opc: It is treated by fully supinating the forearm
opd: It is dislocation of the radial head

question: In a fracture shaft humerus which of the following complication requires immediate surgery:
exp: Indications of emergency surgery in ohopaedics: Compament syndrome Vascular injury Open injury Joint dislocation/subluxation Progressive neural injury Compound/open injury: It is relatively lesser emergency as compared to vascular injury. In case of open injuries we can still wait for up to 12 to 24 hours. Nerve injury: Nerve injury in case of closed fracture of humerous is due to neuropraxia and usually function returns in about 6 months if managed conservatively. Comminuted fracture: It is not an emergent indication for surgery.

question: Which of the following is not a classification of humerus?
exp: Neer's is used for proximal humerus fracture Galand's for supracondylar fracture of humerus Milch for lateral condyle of humerus fracture Garden's for fracture of neck of femur

question: Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is seen in?
exp: Lateral epicondyle Fracture: Leads to tardy ulnar nerve palsy - Cubitus Valgus deformity followed by non-union of lateral epicondyle fracture. Normal carrying angle of the elbow is 5-15deg of valgus More than this or an asymmetry between the 2 sides is regarded as a valgus deformity. Tardy ulnar nerve palsy- Weakness of the hand with numbness or tingling of the ulnar fingers

question: AP & lateral view of wrist is given. What is your diagnosis?
exp: FRACTURES OF THE DISTAL THIRD OF THE RADIUS WITH DISLOCATION OF THE DISTAL RADIOULNAR JOINT (GALEAZZI FRACTURE-DISLOCATION) In adults, the treatment of choice isinternal fixation with compression plates. In children, closed reduction is often successful. Montaggia Fracture - proximal third of ulna with dislocation of radial head. Smith fracture -distal end of radius with volar displacement. Colles fracture-extra aicular fracture of DER with dorsal displacement.

question: Mallet finger is caused by injury to extensor tendon inseion at:
exp: MALLET FINGER/BASEBALL FINGER- avulsion of extensor tendon of the distal interphalangeal joint from its inseion at the base of distal phalanx. Cause due to direct trauma, occurs when the finger tip is forcibly bent during active extension Treatment An acute mallet finger should be splinted and the DIP joint is kept in hyperextension for 6-8 weeks. Old lesion need treatment if deformity is marked, hand functions seriously impaired, and joint still mobile. The options include fusion, tendon reconstruction or fowler' central slip tenotomy.

question: Hotchkiss terrible triad does not include which of the following injuries?
exp: A Hotchkiss traumatic injury pattern of the elbow characterized by elbow dislocation(often associated with posterolateral dislocation or LCL injury) radial head or neck fracture coronoid process fracture Olecranon fracture is not the pa of terrible triad.

question: Fasciotomy -all of the following are cut except:
exp: Fasciotomy must release skin, superficial fascia and deep fascia. Fig. Forearm fasciotomy Fasciotomy is an emergency procedure used to release pressure in compament syndrome either due to trauma or infections.

question: Game keepers thumb is:
exp: GAME KEEPER'S/SKIER'S THUMB Injury to the thumb metacarpophalangeal joint ulnar collateral ligament- most common injury of 1st MCP joint. Pain, swelling and ecchymosis around the metacarpophalangeal joint. On clinical examination, a prominent lump can be palpated, which represents the ulnar collateral ligament being displaced by the adductor aponeurosis.
opa: Thumb metacarpophalangeal joint ulnar collateral ligament rupture
opb: Thumb metacarpophalangeal joint radial collateral ligament rupture
opc: Thumb interphalangeal joint ulnar collateral ligament rupture
opd: Thumb interphalangeal joint radial collateral ligament rupture

question: In myositis ossificans mature bone is seen:
exp: In myositis ossificans, there is peripheral ossification and central lucency of the mass Osteosarcoma- growth in to out Myositis ossificans- growth out to in I. O. C is CT SCAN The mass is usually separated from underlying bone by at least a thin line

question: Clavicular fracture is usually treated by:
exp: Clavicular fracture Inferior displacement of the lateral fragment in clavicle fractures is due to gravity acting on the I/L arm. The medial segment is held up by the action of the SCM Clavicle Fracture Treatment:- A figure-of-8 bandage-the purpose of immobilisation, and gives pain relief. Open reduction and internal fixation is required, either when the fracture is associated with neurovascular deficit, or in some severely displaced fractures, where it may be more of a cosmetic concern. In such cases, the fracture is fixed internally with a plate or a nail.

question: First muscle to be involved in Volkmann's ischemic contracture of the forearm?
exp: VOLKMANN'S ISCHAEMIC CONTRACTURE Following aerial injury, patient develops ischaemic contractures of the affected muscles. Shoening of the intrinsic muscles in the hand produces a characteristic deformity: Flexion at the MCP joints Extension of the IP joints Adduction of the thumb ( 'intrinsic-plus' hand). Nerves injured by ischaemia sometimes recover, at least paially; thus the patient presents with deformity and stiffness, but numbness is inconstant. The most commonly affected sites are the forearm and hand, leg and foot. The earliest muscle involved is Flexor digitorum Profundus. In a severe case affecting the forearm, there will be wasting of the forearm and hand, and clawing of the fingers.

question: Garden spade deformity is seen in:
exp: Smith fracture - reverse Colles due to malunion in smith fracture = "Garden Spade Deformity" In colles fracture malunion-dinner fork deformity is seen extra aicular fracture of DER with dorsal displacement. Baon's fracture: The true Baon's fracture is a split of the volar edge of the distal radius with anterior (volar) subluxation of the wrist. This has been reduced and held with a small anterior plate Bennett's fracture is an oblique, simple intra-aicular fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone. Chauffeur's fracture, also known as Hutchinson fracture, is a type of fracture of the forearm, specifically the radial styloid process.

question: What is application of Plaster of Paris all around the surface called?
exp: Plaster of Paris with water:- When applied on one surface - Slab When applied all around- Cast When goes around the spine (limb+spine) - Spica

question: Which of the following is not true for various angles with the sites of fracture?.
exp: Baumann angle is for supracondylar fracture of humerus. Baumann's angle is created by drawing a line parallel to the longitudinal axis of the humeral shaft and a line along the lateral condylar physis as viewed on the AP image Normal is 70-75deg, but best judge is a comparison of the contralateral side Kite's angle calculated in club foot Cobb's - scoliosis Gissan's - calcaneus
opc: Baumann - lateral condyle fracture of femur

question: A patient presents to you with musculoskeletal complaints. The main concern is to differentiate aicular versus non aicular origin of pain. Which of the following feature is suggestive of non aicular origin of pain?
exp: Differentiation between aicular and extraaicular joint disorders - Aicular disorders are characterized by internal/deep joint pain that is exacerbated by active and passive motion and by reduced range of motion. - Extraaicular disorders are associated with joint pain with active motion rather than passive motion in addition, range of motion often is preserved.
opa: Pain or decrease range of motion on active and passive movement both
opd: Pain on active movement but not on passive movement

question: Inability to touch the opposite shoulder in dislocated shoulder is known as?
exp: 1) Bryant's test - Lower level of axillary fold which can be observed from a distance in dislocated shoulder. 2) Callaway test -Circumference of axilla lengthens in dislocated shoulder. 3) Dugas test - Inability to touch the opposite shoulder in dislocated shoulder 4) Hamilton ruler test - When ruler placed on lateral epicondyle ruler touch lateral epicondyle and acromion simultaneously in dislocated shoulder. (normally it can't)

question: Most common affected tendon in the Swimmer's shoulder?
exp: Swimmer's shoulder /supraspinatus syndrome/ Painful arc syndrome/Shoulder impingement syndrome. Causes of swimmer's shoulder: Supraspinatus tendinitis - Most common cause Complete or paial rupture of the rotator cuff Osteoahritis of the acromioclavicular joint

question: A person had an oblique fracture of olecranon which was displaced proximally. The treatment is:
exp: - Fracture of the olecranon in adults, when the fragments are separated, open reduction and internal fixation are necessary by Tension Band Wiring. - Tension band wiring is also done in case of fracture of patella and medial malleolus.

question: Commonest type of shoulder dislocation:
exp: Anterior Dislocation of Shoulder--Most Common Type of Shoulder Dislocation Types: Subcoracoid>Preglenoid>Subclavicular Mechanism of Injury: Abduction and External rotation force.
